Question_1.Context: The study investigated the effect of applying exogenous biodegradable chelating agents to zinc-contaminated soil on zinc uptake by industrial hemp varieties.
Question_1.Question: What was the effect of applying Nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA) on zinc accumulation in the above-ground parts of the 'Felina 32' variety?
Question_1.Source: After the application of NTA at a concentration of 5 mmol L−1, a > threefold increased accumulation of Zn in the above-ground parts was recorded in the ‘Felina 32’ variety.

Question_2.Context: The study focused on the impact of applying different chelating agents to zinc-contaminated soil on soil microbial activity.
Question_2.Question: How did the application of Citric acid (CA) affect dehydrogenase activity in the soil?
Question_2.Source: CA application was coupled with significantly (p ≤ 0.05) increased dehydrogenase activity in both ‘Felina 32’ and ‘Monoica’-planted soil variants compared to the control.

Question_3.Context: The study examined the impact of Nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA) and Citric acid (CA) on zinc accumulation in industrial hemp varieties.
Question_3.Question: Which chelating agent showed a significant increase in zinc accumulation in the above-ground parts of the 'Monoica' variety?
Question_3.Source: NTA affected the soil microbiome negatively, causing decreased enzyme activity (in ‘Monoica’ planted soil) and induced respiration.

Question_4.Context: The study evaluated the effect of chelating agents on soil enzyme activities in zinc-contaminated soil.
Question_4.Question: What was the impact of Nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA) on n-acetyl-β-d-glucosaminidase (NAG) activity in the soil?
Question_4.Source: NAG was decreased in the FN variant (compared to FK and FC) and in the MC variant (compared to both MK and MN).

Question_5.Context: The study investigated the response of soil microbial activity to different chelating agents in zinc-contaminated soil.
Question_5.Question: How did the application of Citric acid (CA) affect soil basal respiration?
Question_5.Source: CA amendment presented a source of labile and easily utilizable carbon source, which could further induce higher respiration due to its consumption.

Question_6.Context: The study examined the impact of chelating agents on soil enzyme activities in zinc-contaminated soil.
Question_6.Question: What was the effect of Nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA) on phosphatase (Phos) activity in the soil?
Question_6.Source: NTA presumably derived enhanced solubility and extractability of Zn which deteriorated Phos in the ‘Felina 32’ variant.

Question_7.Context: The study focused on the impact of chelating agents on soil microbial activity in zinc-contaminated soil.
Question_7.Question: How did the application of Nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA) affect D-glucose-induced respiration in the soil?
Question_7.Source: D-glucose-induced respiration (Glc-SIR) determination showed that maximal microbial potential for respiration was significantly decreased in all NTA-treated variants.

Question_8.Context: The study examined the impact of chelating agents on soil enzyme activities in zinc-contaminated soil.
Question_8.Question: What was the effect of Citric acid (CA) on arylsulfatase (ARS) activity in the soil?
Question_8.Source: Only the variant with MC had significantly lower ARS (p ≤ 0.05) than all other variants, which arylsulfatase activity was comparable to each other.

Question_9.Context: The study investigated the response of soil microbial activity to different chelating agents in zinc-contaminated soil.
Question_9.Question: How did the application of Nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA) affect D-mannose-induced respiration in the soil?
Question_9.Source: The observed substrate-induced respirations in the MC variant (Man-SIR and Pro-SIR) were significantly (p ≤ 0.05) the highest, presumably not due to the strongest stress-induced enhancement of metabolism.

Question_10.Context: The study examined the impact of chelating agents on soil enzyme activities in zinc-contaminated soil.
Question_10.Question: What was the effect of Citric acid (CA) on β-glucosidase (GLU) activity in the soil?
Question_10.Source: Only the variant with MC had significantly lower ARS (p ≤ 0.05) than all other variants, which arylsulfatase activity was comparable to each other.
